Literature Review: Negative-stranded RNA viruses are a diverse group of pathogens that infect a wide range of hosts, including humans. These viruses encode their genomes in RNA across multiple segments in an orientation antisense to messenger RNA, which is a characteristic feature of segmented, negative-sense RNA viruses (SNSRVs). The development of reverse genetic systems has been a crucial step in understanding the genetic systems of these viruses, and this review aims to provide an overview of the conserved approaches illustrated by some of the prominent members of SNSRV families that cause significant human disease. We will also describe the utility of their genetic systems in the development of reporter strains of the viruses and some biological insights made possible by their use. Finally, we will highlight some possible future uses of reporter viruses that not only will increase our basic understanding of how these viruses replicate and cause disease but also could inform the development of new approaches to therapeutically intervene.
